title: LPFO, gas shortage retard cement production capacity to 20 MMT
text:
Home » Business » LPFO, gas shortage retard cement production capacity to 20 MMT LPFO, gas shortage retard cement production capacity to 20 MMT On 11:21 pm In Business by adekunle Comments 
By Franklin Alli ACUTE shortages of industrial fuel such as low pour fuel (LPFO), automotive gas oil (AGO) and natural gas have retarded local cement production capacity to 20 million metric tonnes. 
The major producers are Dangote, Lafarge and BUA Group. 
According to Cement Manufacturers Association of Nigeria (CMAN) despite the massive investment in cement manufacturing by the producers in the last twelve years, local production is still peaking at 20 million metric tonnes from an initial 2.0 million metric tonnes. 
CMAN said that although the combined installed capacities of these plants are over 28 million tonnes, their target is to deliver 40 to 50 million metric tonnes by 2020, but added: “What can we do when there is no fuel oil and gas?” 
Investigations further revealed that due to the fuel shortages, Dangote Cement has slowed down its growth strategy in response to ‘challenging’ markets in Nigeria and the rest of Africa. The group now intends to focus on a five-year building programme to better balance funding and investment. 
Switching to coal power 
It was further learned that the company has switched to using coal at its cement plants across the country in response to disruption to gas supplies and to lower input costs. 
The company reported that its fuels costs rose by 32.3 percent to $14.4/t in 2016. The cement producer intends to use 12,000t/day of coal. 
All our cement plants have been converted to coal,” said owner, Aliko Dangote. 
Intermittent periods 
Similarly, Alhaji Abdulsamad Rabiu, the chairman of BUA Group, said its subsidiary, the Cement Company of Northern Nigeria (CCNN) was forced to shut down its Sokoto cement plant for intermittent periods in late 2015 due to poor supplies of low pour fuel oil (LFPO) from the Kaduna refinery. 
He noted that imported inputs such as fuel, machinery, spare parts and gypsum would all affect the price of cemment. 
Also, Production managers at Lafarge Africa’s cement plants at Ewekoro and Sagamu, Ogun State have complained about poor supplies of gas. 
Segun Shoyoye and Hannes Diedericks said that the situation started in early 2016 and has led to low production at the plants. 
“The major issue is lack of gas supply because of the blowing up of oil and gas pipelines by militants in the Niger Delta region. We are now using a mixture of gas and black oil for our operations, which is highly costly, and also drops our production from 100 per cent to 75 percent at the Ewekoro plant. This has been going on since February 2016,” said Shoyoye. 
He added that production at Sagamu stopped for six weeks in May 2016. Production has dropped from 3000t/day to 1000t/day due to the issue. 
Lafarge Africa is currently sourcing alternative sources of energy for its cement plants. 
Vanguard further learned that Lafarge Africa has signed a $35million contract with Chinese company Rughn Power to build a 16MW captive power plant at its Ashaka cement plant in Gombe State. 
The lignite burning plant should provide a reliable energy source for the plant to increase its cement production capacity to 1Mt/yr. adekunle
